section1List.hed: How to Become Shamelessly Obsessed With Honey in 12 Easy Steps
section1List.dek: When our writer fell in love with honey, she fell in love *hard*and her cooking life became all the better for it. Now, she shares how you, too, can become a honey addict.
section1List.promoHed: An Obsessive's Guide to Buying and Cooking With Honey
section1List.body:
The addiction started eight years ago. I was visiting the [Union Square Greenmarket](http://www.grownyc.org/greenmarket/manhattan-union-square-m) for the first time, and there was a local beekeeper there. He had samples. 

Free samples. 

Lots of them. 

Up until then I'd only tasted the overly sweet, one-note honeys that line most grocery store shelves. But these honeys were different. They were nuanced and complex. They smelled like flowers. 

I bought a jar and brought it home. And ever since, I've been on a rampage, picking up a jar or two of local honey whenever I travel and precariously pining over the shelves at speciality food stores. 

Now, my pantry is crammed. The shelves are sticky. They sag under the jars' weight. 

I'm not alone in this addiction. "There's something about honey that can just hook you in," says [Rebekah Peppler](http://rebekahpeppler.com/), Brooklyn-based food stylist and author of [*Honey*](http://shortstackeditions.com/store/volume-8). She's gone down the honey rabbit hole, too. 

This is how to fall down that hole yourself.

##Step 1: Learn How Honey Happens##
A fascination with honey often starts with a fascination of how honey is made, a natural process that is as complex and perfect as anything happening at, say, Apple. To put it briefly: Honey is made from the nectar of flowers. Bees suck the nectar from flower blooms and store it in their stomachs. While there, the nectar mixes with protein and enzymes, which breaks the nectar down from sucrose into glucose and fructose. Once at the hive, the bees deposit the converted nectar into the cells of the hive and fan it with their wings until enough moisture evaporates that it has become the thick syrup we know as honey. The bees cap the cells with wax for storage (because honey isn't just food for usbees feed on it as well), which indicates to a beekeeper that the honey can be collected.

##Step 2: Align yourself with a varietal##
Like wine, honey can be blends of several nectars, or they can be made solely with one type of nectar. A proper honey addict is familiar with the most common single-varieties, has respect for all of them, but has a few he or she loves more than the others. A few of the more than 300 varieties in the United States:

 - [Acacia](http://www.thegourmetonline.com/acaia-organic-honey-p/mt01ac.htm): From the yellow clusters of flowers of acacia trees, this is the sweetest, most delicate honey available. It's clear and almost agave-like.
 - [Clover](http://www.solabeefarms.com/white_sweet_clover): Floral and mild. The most readily-available variety and good for all-purpose use.
 - [Tupelo](http://savannahbee.com/tupelo/): From the flowers of Tupelo trees that grow in the swamps of north Florida, this is an extremely rare honey that has a clear, gold-toned color and a rich, buttery flavor.
 - [Orange Blossom](https://beeraw.com/raw-honey-collection/single-varietal-honey/orange-blossom-honey-113.html): Another great all-purpose honey, made from the white flowers of orange trees. Perfectly sweet, with fresh citrus undertones.
 - [Buckwheat](https://beeraw.com/buckwheat-honey-136.html): One of the most robust varieties, from the flowers of the buckwheat plant. It's color is deep, dark brown and its flavor is reminiscent of molasses.
 - [Chestnut](http://www.thegourmetonline.com/heather-honey-p/mt03-chest.htm): Another honey that isn't messing around. Strong and slightly bitter. This personal addict's favorite.

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55524925644d45515b751d25]||||||

+++

##Step 3: respect the blend##
"When we place honey bees in an area where certain flowers are in bloom, we get that variety of honey," says Claire Tauzer, General Manager of [Sola Bee Farms](http://www.solabeefarms.com/). Beekeepers will shuttle bees to certain locations to yield single-variety honeysa clover field, say, to make clover honey.

But honey made from various types of flowers is also possible. "Honey bees will stick to a single source of nectar and pollen if it is clean and high quality. That said, in many areas and seasons there are many different types of plants blooming that are all healthy and nutritious for honey bees. This is why you get seasonal honey and varietals with more than one flower source, like [wildflower](http://www.solabeefarms.com/wine_country_wildflower) honey."

It's perfectly acceptable to become addicted to a high-quality blend. 

##Step 4: Go through thick and thin##
Honey addicts will quickly realize that every honey has its own consistencysome are translucent and flow freely, others creamy and spreadable, and a few thick and practically solid. This is due to the chemical makeup of the nectar that made the honey: the more glucose in the honey, the more likely it will be dense and opaque; the more fructose, the clearer and thinner the honey will be. 

Honey addicts should embrace all honeys, regardless of its consistency, including crystallized honey. Tauzer notes: "Quality honey can be crystalized in the jar, which is actually a good thing. It shows that the honey you are buying has not been watered down or overheated and filtered." 

Crystallized honey can be restored to its smooth, liquid consistency by placing the jar in warm water. But a true addict will spread it on toast as-is.

##Step 5: Let go of the honey bear##
At this point in your addiction you'll begin to suspect that the honey you've been pouring from those cute plastic bears all your life is amateur stuff. Not enough flavor. Eerily consistent. 

It stings, but you're on the right path.

Honey bears "are not bad in and of themselves," says Tauzer. "But historically they have been used by very large importers of honey from China and other countries. It's hard to track the origin or actual flower source of these honeys, and if you don't know where it comes from, I wouldn't trust it."

Zeke Freeman, founder of [Bee Raw](https://beeraw.com/), concurs. "It's honey, but it's honey that has been ultra-filtered to remove all traces of pollen and has likely been diluted with less expensive sugars  to make it cheaper. Not having any pollen hides the original source of honey and makes it very difficult to tell if other less expensive sugars have been used to dilute the honey."

Time to let go of those honey bears, addict. Use up whatever bears you have lingering in your pantry, then kiss them goodbye.

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55524925100d9bda6d81a398]||||||

+++

##Step 6: Seek out raw experiences##

Raw honey is honey that hasn't been heated past pasteurization. Because of this "it most likely has all of its beneficial pollen, amino acids and enzymes intact," says Freeman. Addicts like raw honey, because it has more nuance.

##Steps 7-12: Use honey everywhere##

How do addicts cook with honey? The better question is how do they *not*? 

Morning honeyspread thick on toast or drizzled onto Greek yogurt or oatmealis the gateway meal for most addicts. 

[#recipe: /recipes/54a41fac6529d92b2c007ab7]|||
Yogurt with Fresh Figs, Honey, and Pine Nuts
|||

Roast meat and vegetables take particularly well to honey, caramelizing them and bringing out their rich flavors. "Orange Blossom honey has all these gorgeous citrus flavors, so combine it with lemon and brush it over roast chicken," Peppler says. Just note that honey can burn, so brush it on your roast during the last 10 to 15 minutes of cooking. 

[#recipe: /recipes/54a4212d19925f464b37833c]|||
Honey-Roasted Cherry Tomatoes
|||

Honey addicts drink their honey as often as they eat it. "I keep a [honey simple syrup](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/honey-syrup-236307) in my fridge at all times," says Peppler. Experiment with different honeys: delicate [Clover honey](https://beeraw.com/raw-honey-collection/sweet-yellow-clover-honey.html) is a great match with gin, as it won't compete with its herbal notes, while spicy, molasses-like Buckwheat honey can stand up to darker spirits like rum and whiskey.

[#recipe: /recipes/54a41eb36529d92b2c007343]|||
Saint-Florent Cocktail
|||

"Salad dressings are a great way to learn the different flavors of honey," says Peppler. Let the honey you reach for mimic the greens you are dressing: a strong, slightly bitter honey like [Chestnut](http://www.thegourmetonline.com/heather-honey-p/mt03-chest.htm) stands up well to kale or radicchio, while mild [Acacia](http://www.thegourmetonline.com/acaia-organic-honey-p/mt01ac.htm) is a better match for delicate greens like butter lettuce.

[#recipe: /recipes/54a452ff19925f464b38f407]|||
Honey Mustard Dressing and Mixed Greens
|||

Another well-loved combination is cheese and honey, a pairing that instantly upgrades a ho-hum cheese board. But which honeys to choose? Peppler recommends looking at the region that both are madeif the cheese and honey are produced in the same area, it's likely that they will go perfectly together. [Lavender honey](https://www.zingermans.com/Product.aspx?ProductID=P-LAV), which hails from Provence, France, is floral and not too sweet and pairs perfectly with fresh, tangy goat cheese, which is also produced all over the region.

[#recipe: /recipes/54a4218119925f464b3786d2]|||
Peach and Blue Cheese Toasts
|||

The final frontier of cooking with honey: [baking with honey](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/which-healthier-sweet-tooth-guide-is-right-for-you-article). Since it's sweeter and more liquid than granulated sugar, you'll want to "err on the side of less honey than sugaryoull wipe out your tastebuds with one to one ratio," says Peppler. You'll also need to reduce the other liquids called for in the recipe. This requires a bit of trial and error. Not willing to play around? Other than [using a recipe that intentionally calls for honey](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/orange-blossom-honey-madeleines-367764), the other no-fail option is to reach for recipes that call for other liquid sweeteners like [maple syrup](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/maple-pear-sheet-tart-51253810) and molasses and swap honey in.

[#recipe: /recipes/54a4281119925f464b37cd81]|||
Honey Cake
|||

section1List.hed: How I Mastered Honey Cake for Rosh Hashanah
section1List.dek: After years of searching, I found the one recipe that gets this traditional dessert right.
section1List.promoHed: The Rosh Hashanah Honey Cake You'll Actually Love
section1List.body:
What if I told you to celebrate the New Year with a slice of dry, sickly-sweet cake made from the syrupy secretions of an insect? Not such a great idea, right? 

Well, unfortunately, most people who celebrate the Jewish New Year, or Rosh Hashanah, have been suffering needlessly under the tyranny of this strange confection for generations. Honey cake, meant to symbolize the sweetness we hope to find in the year to come, never turns out as tasty as it sounds. 

But every year, brimming with blind optimism, I'd select a new honey cake recipe to try, hoping that instead of a dark, bready, and dense slab, I'd find an irresistible, moist, honey-scented cake. And every year, I'd be cruelly disappointed.

That was the sorry state of affairs until I finally tried Marcy Goldman's [Majestic and Moist New Year's Honey Cake](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/majestic-and-moist-new-years-honey-cake-350153).

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55e85ba2cf90d6663f728010]|||
Just look at those toasty, crackly almonds.
|||

+++

I should have known to go straight to Marcyher [Caramel Matzoh Crunch](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/my-trademark-most-requested-absolutely-magnificent-caramel-matzoh-crunch-109117) is a legendary treat for Passover. And unlike the slew of honey cakes in my past, hers didn't disappoint. The blend of spice, honey sweetness, and a tender, moist crumb was what I'd been searching for all along. I've made her recipe for every Rosh Hashanah ever since.

This year, I decided to go straight to the source (Goldman herself) to find out just what makes her genre-shattering honey cake so good:

##More richness##

"I wasn't a fan of traditional honey cake," Goldman says. "It was dry, heavy, and dark, and 80% of the people I talked to hated it." So she used her knowledge as a pastry chef to unpack the recipe and figure out what was wrong with it. "Typical honey cakes have about 75% less fat than most cakes," Goldman said. The batters still seemed liquidy because of all that honey, but the lack of oil made the texture of the cake dry and dense. So she upped the oil, creating a batter that bakes up moist and light.

##Layers of sweetness##
Most honey cakes rely on, well, honey for their sweetness. But Goldman discovered that adding two kinds of sugar helps improve the cake's texture even more. "A combination of granulated and brown sugars helps give the cake lift," she points out. And if you're open to non-kosher honeys, choosing a flavorful variety like linden, buckwheat, or clover can add even more nuance, Goldman points out.

##Deeper flavor##
Coffee is a traditional flavoring in honey cake, but that flavor on its own can be a little dull. Goldman adds orange juice and rye whiskey to round out coffee's bitterness. And while many honey cakes clobber you with powerful spices like clove and allspice, Goldman recalibrated the mix to focus on the gentler taste of cinnamon instead. "It's a better balance of spices," Goldman says. Sounds pretty sweet to me.

[#recipe: /recipes/54a408a26529d92b2c003631]|||
Majestic and Moist New Year's Honey Cake
|||

Dont be surprised if people start pestering you for the recipe after their first bite.

section1List.hed: For Some Apples, Summer is the Season
section1List.dek: How do we like *these* apples? In July and August.
section1List.promoHed: Think the Season for Apples is the Fall? Think Again
section1List.socialTitle: Summer's Surprise Fruit is Extra Crisp and Tart
section1List.body:
It may be the middle of [blueberry](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes-menus/the-secret-to-the-ultimate-blueberry-muffins-article), [melon](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/salted-and-spiced-melon-56389726), andsoon[tomato](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/how-to-make-tomatoes-taste-riper-article) season, and yet you can't help it: You find yourself looking ahead to apple season, the season when you throw on a sweater, jump in the car, and watch the leaves change as you pick apples as crisp as the fall air. 

[#article: /articles/54e605bde77a7de93306069f]||||||

This is totally normal and nothing to be ashamed of. But it's also unnecessary. You don't have to look ahead to apple season. Because apple season is actually already here.

Summer apples are an overlooked class of apples that come into season in late July and early August. They've got yellow skins and intense flavorsmuch more tart and savory than their autumnal counterparts. 

Todd Nichols of [Nichols Farm in Marengo, Illinois](https://www.nicholsfarm.com/our-story)  has been farming for three generations and experimenting with summer apples for 38 years. Summer apples are all about freshness, he says. And these are four of the freshest varieties at the markets right now:

####Lodi####
Bought at their peak, these look like a less shiny version of Granny Smith. Created in 1924 as a [cross between Yellow Transparent and Montgomery](http://www.starkbros.com/products/fruit-trees/apple-trees/stark-lodi-apple), this variety of summer apple shows up in many farmers markets during the last weeks in July. Theyre green and tough-skinned, with a tart, almost lemony flavor. Chop them and mix them into [a chicken salad](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/grilled-curried-chicken-salad-and-pita-230302). 

[#recipe: /recipes/54a428df6529d92b2c00dc51]||||||

####Yellow Transparent####
Dating back to Russian origins in the 1800s, yellow transparents have a [pale yellow skin with white and greenish dots](http://www.orangepippin.com/apples/yellow-transparent). Depending on where you are in the country, you may start seeing these in mid-July. Look for smooth skin thats practically transparent when its ripe. The fruit is roundish, conical, and mildly acidicand its perfect for a tart snack, in an applesauce, or for juicing.

[#recipe: /recipes/54a41e6e6529d92b2c0071b1]||||||

####Pristine####
Think of this as your gateway summer apple: It's a [sweeter variety](http://www.saltspringapplecompany.com/Pristine.htm) similar to Golden Delicious. Look for Pristines that are yellow with a red blush.

####Red Astrachans####
Whereas many summer are a shade of pale yellow, Red Astrachans (introduced in the U.S.A. in 1835) explode with a deep red color that's broken up with streaks of pink. When cooked, these have a pronounced quince (not to mention a reddish hue).

(A few other summer apples to keep an eye out for: [Chenango Strawberry](https://www.albemarleciderworks.com/product/trees/chenango-strawberry-apple-tree), [Carolina June](http://www.centuryfarmorchards.com/descripts/crj.html), [St. Lawrence](https://outonalimbcsa.wordpress.com/st-lawrence/), and [Summer Rambo](http://bighorsecreekfarm.com/summer-rambo-2/).)

Summer apples only stick around for a few weeks, and they don't keep forever. Left on the countertop, they'll turn mealy in just  few days. Refrigerated, they'll last a little longer. Still, you want to eat these guys pretty quickly. And why not? More apples are just a few weeks away.
section1List.seoDescription: How to cook with summer apples like Lodi and Pristine.
section1List.socialDescription: And it's in season right this very second.

section1List.hed: The Easiest Ways to Keep Your Apples From Browning
section1List.dek: Slice an apple and before you can even get your snack on, it starts to turn brown. Here's what to do about it.
section1List.promoHed: Your Apples Will Never Brown Again
section1List.body:
No matter how crisp and juicy an apple may be, no one will want to eat it once it's turned brown. Apples brown when the flesh of the fruit is exposed to oxygen, and it's enough of a problem that that the [USDA just approved] (http://www.cnn.com/2015/02/16/health/apples-genetically-modified-usda/) an apple that's genetically modified to not brown when sliced (it's America's first approved genetically modified appleyay?). That apple won't be in markets until at least 2016. Until then, here are a few old-fashioned tricks to prevent sliced apples from oxidizing:

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/54e658004f77a310045d66d4]||||||

+++

##Citrus or Pineapple Juice##
What do these juices have in common? They contain citric acid, which prevents oxidation and browning. If you're going the citrus route, simply squeeze your lemon, lime, or orange directly onto the surface of the cut apple. Otherwise, soak the fruit in the juice. Whichever juice you use, be aware that it will impart a little bit of flavor onto the apple, so pick your favorite.

##Salt & Water##
Dissolve 1/8 teaspoon of salt into one cup of water, add your apple slices, let them soak for a few minutes, then drain them. Give the slices a quick rinse in fresh water after you drain them, so your fruit won't taste salty.

##Honey & Water##
Stir two tablespoons of honey into one cup of water and soak your apple slices in the mixture for 30 seconds. This works because there is a compound in honey that stops the enzyme responsible for oxidization.
section1List.seoTitle: Easy Ways to Stop Apples From Browning
section1List.seoDescription: Slice up an apple and before you can even get your snack on, it starts to turn brown. Never let an apple turn brown again.
section1List.socialTitle: The Easiest Ways to Keep Your Apples From Browning
section1List.socialDescription: Slice up an apple and before you can even get your snack on, it starts to turn brown. Never let an apple turn brown again.

section3List.dek: What's wonderful about challah is that it can be used in so many ways: to sanctify the Sabbath, of course, but just as important, to make French toast, grilled cheese, and croutons and as breading in meatballs. Maybe not the way God intended it, but I'm sure She understands. Israel is the land of milk and honey, and this challah has both. For those of you who want to stay away from milk, it's fine to substitute water.

section2List.dek: I can't believe I'd never heard of this recipe until I was halfway through writing this cookbook and then only because my good friend Fran McCullough, a primo New York cookbook editor now retired and living in the historic town of Hillsborough just north of Chapel Hill, e-mailed one morning full of enthusiasm: "Have you ever heard of Atlanta Brisket?" She'd eaten it for the first time the night before at some local "food do" and was blown away by its flavor and succulence. A quick online search turned up this shocker. Eli N. Evans, my across-the-hall Gramercy Park co-op neighbor for nearly 20 years, is an aficionado of Atlanta Brisket. Who knew? President Emeritus of The Charles H. Revson Foundation of New York and like me a born-and-bred Tar Heel, Eli is the author of three acclaimed books:  The Provincials: A Personal History of Jews in the South, Judah P. Benjamin: The Jewish Confederate,  and  The Lonely Days Were Sundays: Reflections of a Jewish Southerner.  The irony here is that I'd hand recipe "tests" across the hall to Eli and his family, never dreaming that he knew a thing about cooking.
section2List.promoDek: I can't believe I'd never heard of this recipe until I was halfway through writing this cookbook and then only because my good friend Fran McCullough, a primo New York cookbook editor now retired and...

section2List.dek: This is the go-to recipe for knowledgeable brisket lovers. Who then share it with others. Who share it withperhapsthe Obamas and other notable families. So warm and welcoming, the secret is what Nach did way before anyone else: slice the meat midway through cooking. If you serve this the day after you make it, reheat, covered, for about 1 hour in a 325F oven.

section2List.dek:
No one will fault you for
seasoning brisket with salt and pepper,
braising it in beer, and calling it a day. But
follow chef Lee's methodwhich calls
for a bath of stout, bourbon, and soy sauce;
a glaze made with peach jam; and a
side of easy  homemade pickles 
 if you'd
likeand you're on the path
to savory-and-sweet nirvana.

section2List.dek:
Beef brisket is the centerpiece of many Jewish holiday meals, particularly at Passover, and every family has their favorite way of preparing it. There are countless recipes out there, but how many do you need besides your grandmother's? At least one more: This one!
 
Why? Because the meat is slowly braised in Pinot Noir, and the cherry notes in the wine pair brilliantly with dried tart cherries, which plump up with winey beef juices to become little mini-pouches of flavor on their own. Add to that a bit of star anise, which perfumes the brisket  and  your home with an exotic and enticing hint of licorice. Season the mixture with the sweet-and-sour agrodolce dance of brown sugar and balsamic vinegar, and you have a brisket that is at once counterintuitively familiar and wonderfully different. Like all braised meats, brisket improves in flavor, and slices more easily, if made a day ahead and chilled (see Cooks' Notes).
  
  Editor's Note:   This recipe is part of  Gourmet's  Modern Menu for Passover. Menu also includes  Quinoa and Asparagus Salad with Mimosa Vinaigrette 
 and  Amaretto Olive Oil Cake.

section2List.dek:
The brisket tastes best if
prepared ahead, so make it at least one
day and up to two days before you plan to
serve it. Chilling the brisket makes it easier
to slice. Rewarm the meat in the sauce and
serve with a full-flavored dark beer (see
our suggestions below).
